titleStmt.title: The Convent of Pleasure. A Comedy

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.p: Tom, Where have you been, you look so sadly of it?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: I have been at the Funeral of the Lord Fortunate; who has left his Daugther, the Lady Happy, very rich having no other Daugther but her.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: If she be so rich, it will make us all Young Men, spend all our Wealth on fine Clothes, Coaches, and Lackies, to fet out our Wooing hopes.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent
sp.p: If all her Wooers be younger Brothers, as most of us Gallants are, we shall undo our selves upon bare hopes, without Probability: But is she hansome, Tom?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Yes, she is extream handsome, young, rich, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: Faith, that is too much for one Woman to possess.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Not, if you were to have her.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: No, not for me; but in my Opinion too much for any other Man.

div.head: Scente II.
div.stage: [Enter the Lady Happy, and one of her Attendants.]

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Madam, you being young, hansome, rich, and virtuous, I hope you will not cast away those gifts of Nature, Fortune, and Heaven, upon a Person which cannot merit you?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Let me tell you, that Riches ougt to be bestowed on such as are poor, and want means to maintain themselves; and Youth, on those that are old, Beauty, on those that are ill-favoured; and Virtue, on those that are vicious: So that if I should place my gifts rightly, I must Marry one that's poor, old, ill-favoured, and debauch'd.

sp.speaker: Serv
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Nay, Heaven doth not allow of it, but commands it; for we are commanded to give to those that want.

div.stage: [Enter Madam Mediator to the Lady Happy.]

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Surely, Madam, you do but talk, and intend not to go where you say.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Yes, truly, my Words and Intentions go even together.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: But surely you will no incloyster your self, as you say.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Why, what is there in the publick World that should invite me to live in it?

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: More then if you should banish your self from it.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Put the case I should Marry the best of Men, if any best there be; yet would a Marry'd life have more crosses and sorrows then pleasure, freedom, or hapiness: nay Marriage to those that are virtuous is a greater restraint then a Monastery. Or, should I take delight in Admirers? they might gaze on my Beauty, and praise my Wit, and I receive nothing from their eyes, nor lips; for Words vanish as soon as spoken, and Sights are not substantial. Besides, I should lose more of my Reputation by their Visits, then gain by their Praises. Or, should I quit Reputation and turn Courtizan, there would be more lost in my Health, then gained by my Lovers, I should find more pain then Pleasure; besides, the troubles and frights I should put to, with the Quarrels and Brouilleries that Jealous Rivals make, would be a torment to me: and 'tis only for the sake of Men, when Women retire not: And since there is so much folly, vanity and falshood in Men, why should Women trouble and vex themselves for their sake; for retiredness bars the life from nothing else but Men.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: O yes, for those that incloister themselves, bar themselves from all other worldly Pleasures.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: The more Fools they.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Will you call those Fools that do it for the gods sake?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: No Madam, it is not for the gods sake, but for opinion’s sake; for, Can any Rational Creature think or believe, the gods take delight in the Creature’s uneasie life? or, Did they command or give leave to Nature to make Senses for no use; or to cross, vex and pain them? for, What profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men or Women wear coarse Linnen or rough Woollen, or to flea their skin with Hair-cloth, or to eat or sawe thorow their flesh with Cords? or, What profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men eat more Fish then Flesh, or to fast? unless the gods did feed on such meat themselves; for then, for fear the gods should want it, it were fit for Men to abstein from it: The like for Garments, for fear the gods should want fine Clothes to adorn themselves, it were fit Men should not wear them: Or, what profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men to lie uneasily on the hard ground, unless the gods and Nature were at variance, strife and wars; as if what is displeasing unto Nature, were pleasing to the gods, and to be enemies to her, were to be friends to them.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: But being done for the gods sake, it makes that which in Nature seems to be bad, in Divinity to be good.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: It cannot be good, if it be neither pleasure, nor profit to the gods; neither do Men any thing for the gods but their own sake.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: But when the Mind is not imployed with Vanities, nor the Senses with Luxury; the Mind is more free, to offer its Adorations, Prayers and Praises to the gods.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: I believe, the gods are better pleased with Praises then Fasting; but when the Senses are dull’d with abstinency, the Body weakned with fasting, the Spirits tir’d with watching, the Life made uneasie with pain, the Soul can have but little will to worship: only the Imagination doth frighten it into active zeal, which devotion is rather forced then voluntary; so that their prayers rather flow out of their mouth, then spring from their heart, like rain-water that runs thorow Gutters, or like Water that’s forced up a Hill by Artificial Pipes and Cisterns. But those that pray not unto the gods, or praise them more in prosperity then adversity, more in pleasures then pains, more in liberty then restraint, deserve neither the happiness of ease, peace, freedom, plenty and tranquillity in this World, nor the glory and blessedness of the next. And if the gods should take pleasure in nothing but in the torments of their Creatures, and would not prefer those those prayers that are offer’d with ease and delight, I should believe, the gods were cruel: and, What Creature that had reason or rational understanding, would serve cruel Masters, when they might serve a kind Mistress, or would forsake the service of their kind Mistress, to serve cruel Masters? Wherefore, if the gods be cruel, I will serve Nature; but the gods are bountiful, and give all, that’s good, and bid us freely please our selves in that which is best for us: and that is best, what is most temperately used, and longest may be enjoyed, for excess doth wast it self, and all it feeds upon.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: In my opinion your Doctrine, and your Intention do not agree together.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: You intend to live incloister'd and retired from the World.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: 'Tis true, but not from pleasures; for, I intend to incloister my self from the World, to enjoy pleasure, and not to bury my self from it; but to incloister my self from the incumbred cares and vexations, troubles and perturbance of the World.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: But if you incloister your self, How will you enjoy the company of Men, whose conversation is thought the greatest Pleasure?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Men are the only troublers of Women; for they only cross and oppose their sweet delights, and peaceable life; they cause their pains, but not their pleasures. Wherefore those Women that are poor, and have not means to buy delights, and maintain pleasures, are only fit for Men; for having not means to please themselves, they must serve only to please others; but those Women, where Fortune, Nature, and the gods are joined to make them happy, were mad to live with Men, who make the Female sex their slaves; but I will not be so inslaved, but will live retired from their Company. Wherefore, in order thereto, I will take so many Noble Persons of my own Sex, as my Estate will plentifully maintain, such whose Births are greater then their Fortunes, and are resolv’d to live a single life, and vow Virginity: with these I mean to live incloister’d with all the delights and pleasures that are allowable and lawful; My Cloister shall not be a Cloister of restraint, but a place for freedom, not to vex the Senses but to please them.

lg.l: For every Sense shall pleasure take,
And all our Lives shall merry make:
Our Minds in full delight shall joy,
Not vex'd with every idle Toy:
Each Season shall our Caterers be,
To search the Land, and Fish the Sea;
To gather Fruit and reap the Corn,
That's brought to us in Plenty's Horn;
With which we'l feast and please our tast
But not luxorious make a wast.
Wee'l Cloth our selves with softest Silk,
And Linnen fine as white as milk.
Wee'l please our Sight with Pictures rare;
Our Nostrils with perfumed Air.
Our Ears with sweet melodious Sound,
Our Tast with swee delicious Meat,
And savory Sauces we will eat:
Variety each Sense shall feed,
And Change in them new Appetites breed.
Thus will in Pleasure's Convent I
Live with delight, and with it die.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Take-pleasure
sp.p: Dick, Am I fine to day?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Yes, Sir, as fine as Feathers, Ribbons, Gold, and Silver can make you.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Dost through think I shall get the Lady Happy?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Not if it be her fortune to continue in that name.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Because if she Marry your Worship she must change her Name; for the Wife takes the Name of her Husband, and quits her own.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Faith, Dick, if I had her wealth I should be Happy.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It would be according as your Worship would use it; but, on my conscience, you would be more happy with the Ladie’s Wealth, then the Lady would be with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Why should you think so?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Becasue Women never think themselves happy in Marriage.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: You are mistaken; for Women never think themselves happy until they be Married.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: The truth is, Sir, that Women are always unhappy in their thoughts, both before and after Marriage; for, before Marriage they think themselves unhappy for want of a Husband; and after they are Married, they think themselves unhappy for having a Husband.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Indeed Womens thoughts are restless.

div.stage: [Enter Monsieur Facil and Monsieur Adviser, to Monsieur Take-pleasure; all in their Wooing Accoustrements.]

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Gentlemen, I perceive you are all prepared to Woo.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Yes faith, we are all prepared to be Wooers. But whom shall we get to present us to the Lady Happy?

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: We must set on bold faces, and present our selves.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Faith, I would not give my hopes for an indifferent portion.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: The truth is, We are all stuft with Hopes, as Cushions are with Feather.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: O Gentlemen, Gentlemen, we are all utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Why, the Lady Happy hath incloister'd her self, with twenty Ladies more.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: The Devil she hath?

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: The gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Whether it was the devil or the gods that have perswaded her to it, I cannot tell; but gone in she is.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: I hope it is but a blast of Devotion, which sill soon flame out.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: O Madam Mediator, we are all undone, the Lady Happy is incloister’d.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Yes, Gentlemen, the more is the pitty.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Is there no hopes?

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Faith, little.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Let us see the Clergy to perswade her out, for the good of the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Alas Gentlemen! they can do no good, for she is not a Votress to the gods but to Nature.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: If she be a Votress to Nature, you are the only Person fit to be Lady Prioress; and so by your power and authority you may give us leave to visit your Nuns sometimes.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: Not but at a Grate, unless in time of Building, or when they are sick; but howsoever, the Lady Happy is Lady-Prioress her self, and will admit none of the Masculine Sex, not so much as to a Grate, for she will suffer no grates about the Cloister; she has also Women-Physicians, Surgeons and Apothecaries, and she is the chief Confessor her self, and gives what Indulgences or Absolutions she pleaseth: Also, her House, where she hath made her Convent, is so big and convenient, and so strong, as it needs no addition or repair: Besides, she has so much compass of ground within her walls, as there is not only room and place enough for Gardens, Orchards, Walks, Groves, Bowers, Arbours, Ponds, Fountains, Springs and the like; but also conveniency for much Provision, and hath Women for every Office and Employment: for though she hath not above twenty Ladies with her, yet she hath a numerous Company of Female Servants, so as there is no occasion for Men.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: If there be so many Women, there will be the more use for Men: But pray Madam Mediator, give me leave, rightly to understand you, by being more clearly informed: you say, The Lady Happy is become a Votress to Nature; and if she be a Votress to Nature, she must be a Mistress to Men.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, she declares, That she hath avoided the company of Men, by retirement, meerly, because she would enjoy the variety of Pleasures, which are in Nature; of which, she says, Men are Obstructers; for, instead of increasing Pleasure, they produce Pain, and, instead of giving Content, they increase Trouble; instead of making the Femal- Sex Happy, they make them Miserable; for which, she hath banished the Masculine Company for ever.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Her Heretical Opinions ought not to be suffer’d, nor her Doctrine allow’d; and she ought to be examined by a Masculine Synod, and punish’d with a severe Husband, or tortured with a deboist Husband.

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: The best way, Gentlemen, is to make your Complaints, and put up a Petition to the State, with your desires for a Redress.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Your Counsel is good.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: We will follow it, and go presently about it.

stage.emph: [Enter the Lady Happy, with her Ladies; as also Madam Mediator.]

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Ladies, give me leave to desire your Confession, whether or no you repent your Retirement.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.p: Most excellent Lady, it were as probable a repentance could be in Heaven amongst Angels as amongst us.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Now Madam Mediator, let me ask you, Do you condemn my act of Retirement?

sp.speaker: Mediat
sp.p: I approve of it with admiration and wonder, that one that is so young should be so wise.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Now give me leave to inform you, how I have order'd this our Convent of Pleasure; first, I have such things as are for our Ease and Conveniency; next for Pleasure, and Delight; as I have change of Furniture, for my house; according to the four Seasons of the year, especially our Chambers: As in the Spring, our Chambers are hung with Silk-Damask, and all other things suitable to it; and a great Looking- Glass in each Chamber, that we may view our selves and take pleasure in our own Beauties, whilst they are fresh and young; also, I have in each Chamber a Cup- board of such plate, as is useful, and whatsoever is to be used is there ready to be imployed; also, I have all the Floor strew’d with sweet Flowers: In the Summer I have all our Chambers hung with Taffety, and all other things suitable to it, and a Cup-board of Purseline, and of Plate, and all the Floore strew’d every day with green Rushes or Leaves, and Cisterns placed neer our Beds-heads, wherein Water may run out of small Pipes made for that purpose: To invite repose in the Autumn, all our Chambers are hung with Gilt Leather, or Franchipane; also, Beds and all other things suitable; and the Rooms Matted with very fine Mats: In the Winter our Chambers must be hung with Tapestry, and our Beds of Velvet, lined with Sattin, and all things suitable to it, and all the Floor spread over with Turkie Carpets, and a Cup-board of Gilt Plate; and all the Wood for Firing to be Cypress and Juniper; and all the Lights to be Perfumed Wax; also, the Bedding and Pillows are ordered according to each Season; viz. to be stuft with Feathers in the Spring and Autumn, and with Down in the Winter, but in the Summer to be only Quilts, either of Silk, or fine Holland; and our Sheets, Pillows, Table-Clothes and Towels, to be of pure fine Holland, and every day clean; also, the Rooms we eat in, and the Vessels we feed withal, I have according to each Season; and the Linnen we use to our Meat, to be pure fine Diaper, and Damask, and to change it fresh every course of Meat: As for our Galleries, Stair-Cases, and Passages, they shall be hung with various Pictures; and, all along the Wall of our Gallery, as long as the Summer lasts, do stand, upon Pedestals, Flower-pots, with various Flowers; and in the Winter Orange-Trees: and my Gardens to be kept curiously, and flourish, in every Season of all sorts of Flowers, sweet Herbs and Fruits, and kept so as not to have a Weed in it, and all the Groves, Wildernesses, Bowers and Arbours pruned, and kept free from dead Boughs Branches or Leaves; and all the Ponds, Rivolets, Fountains, and Springs, kept clear, pure and fresh: Also, we will have the choisest Meats every Season doth afford, and that every day our Meat, be drest several ways, and our drink cooler or hotter according to the several Seasons; and all our Drinks fresh and pleasing: Change of Garments are also provided, of the newest fashions for every Season, and rich Trimming; so as we may be accoutred properly, and according to our several pastimes: and our Shifts shall be of the finest and purest Linnen that can be bought or spun.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.p: None in this World can be happier.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Now Ladies, let us go to our several Pastimes, if you please.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous
sp.p: Madam, how do you, since you were Married?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: Very well, I thank you.

sp.speaker: L. Amor
sp.p: I am not so well as I wish I were.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Ladies, do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: What News?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Why there is a great Foreign Princess arrived, hearing of the famous Convent of Pleasure, to be one of Nature’s Devotes.

sp.speaker: L. Amor
sp.p: What manner of Lady is she?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: She is a Princely brave Woman truly, of a Masculine Presence.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: But, Madam Mediator, Do they live in such Pleasure as you say? for they’l admit you, a Widow, although not us, by reason we are Wives.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: In so much Pleasure, as Nature never knew, before this Convent was: and for my part, I had rather be one in the Convent of Pleasure, then Emperess of the whole World; for every Lady there enjoyeth as much Pleasure as any absolute Monarch can do, without the Troubles and Cares, that wait on Royalty; besides, none can enjoy those Pleasures They have, unless they live such a retired or retreated life free from the Worlds vexations.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: Well, I wish I might see and know, what Pleasures they enjoy.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: If you were there, you could not know all their Pleasure in a short time, for their Varieties will require a long time to know their several Changes; besides, their Pleasures and Delights vary with the Seasons; so that what with the several Seasons, and the Varieties of every Season, it will take up a whole life’s time.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: But I could judg of their Changes by their single Principles.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: But they have Variety of one and the same kind.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue
sp.p: But I should see the way or manner of them.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: That you might.

div.head: Scene IV.
div.stage: [Enter Monsieur Adviser, Courtly, Take-pleasure, and Facil.]

sp.speaker: Monsieur Courtly
sp.p: Is there no hopes to get those Ladies out of their Convent?

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: No faith, unless we could set the Convent on fire.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: For Jupiter’s sake, let us do it, let’s every one carry a Fire-brand to fire it.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Yes, and smoak them out, as they do a Swarm of Bees.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Let’s go presently about it.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Stay, there is a great Princess there.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: 'Tis true, but when that Princess is gone, we will surely do it.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Yes, and be punish'd for our Villany.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: It will not prove Villany, for we shall do Nature good service.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Why, so we do Nature good service, when we get a Wench with Child, but yet the Civil Laws do punish us for it.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: They are not Civil Laws that punish Lovers.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: But those are Civil Laws that punish Adulterers.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Those are Barbarous Laws that make Love Adultery.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: No, Those are Barbarous that make Adultery Love.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Well, leaving Love and Adultery, They are foolish Women that vex us with their Retirement.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, although we rail at the Lady Happy for Retiring, yet if I had such an Estate as she, and would follow her Example; I make no doubt but you would all be content to encloister your selves with me upon the same conditions, as those Ladies incloister themselves with her.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Not unless you had Women in your Convent.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: Nay, faith, since Women can quit the pleasure of Men, we Men may well quit the trouble of Women.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: But is there no place where we may peak into the Convent?

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: No, there are no Grates, but Brick and Stone-walls.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Let us get out some of the Bricks or Stones.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Alas! the Walls are a Yard-thick.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: But nothing is difficult to Willing-minds.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: My Mind is willing; but my Reason tells me, It is impossible; wherefore, I’le never go about it.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Faith, let us resolve to put our selves in Womens apparel, and so by that means get into the Convent.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: We shall be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: Who will discover Us?

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: We shall discover our Selves.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: We are not such fools as to betray our Selves.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: We cannot avoid it, for, our very Garb and Behaviour; besides, our Voices will discover us: for we are as untoward to make Courtsies in Petticoats, as Women are to make Legs in Breeches; and it will be as great a difficulty to raise our Voices to a Treble- sound, as for Women to press down their Voices to a Base; besides, We shall never frame our Eyes and Mouths to such coy, dissembling looks, and pritty simpering Mopes and Smiles, as they do.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: But we will go as strong lusty Country- Wenches, that desire to serve them in Inferiour Places, and Offices, as Cook-maids, Landry-maids, Dairy- maids, and the like.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: I do verily believe, I could make an indifferent Cook-maid, but not a Laundry, nor a Dairy- maid; for I cannot milk Cows, nor starch Gorgets, but I think I could make a pretty shift, to wash some of the Ladies Night-Linnen.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: But they imploy Women in all Places in their Gardens; and for Brewing, Baking and making all sorts of things; besides, some keep their Swine, and twenty such like Offices and Employments there are which we should be very proper for.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: O yes, for keeping of Swine belongs to Men; remember the Prodigal Son.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Faith, for our Prodigality we might be all Swin-heards.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Also we shall be proper for Gardens, for we can dig, and set, and sow.

sp.speaker: Takepl
sp.p: And we are proper for Brewing.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: We are more proper for Drinking, for I can drink good Beer, or Ale, when ’tis Brew’d; but I could not brew such Beer, or Ale, as any man could drink.

sp.speaker: Facil
sp.p: Come, come, we shall make a shift one way or other: Besides, we shall be very willing to learn, and be very diligent in our Services, which will give good and great content; wherefore, let us go and put these designes into execution.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Content, content.

sp.speaker: Adviser
sp.p: Nay, faith, let us not trouble our Selves for it, 'tis in vain.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: [Enter the Princess, and the Lady Happy, with the rest of the Ladies belonging to the Convent.]

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Madam, Your Highness has done me much Honour, to come from a Splendid Court to a retired Convent.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Sweet Lady Happy, there are many, that have quit their Crowns and Power, for a Cloister of Restraint; then well may I quit a Court of troubles for a Convent of Pleasure: but the greatest pleasure I could receive, were, To have your Friendship.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: I should be ungrateful, should I not be not only your Friend, but humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: I desire you would be my Mistress, and I your Servant; and upon this agreement of Friendship I desire you will grant me one Request.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Any thing that is in my power to grant.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Why then, I observing in your several Recreations, some of your Ladies do accoustre Themselves in Masculine-Habits, and act Lovers-parts; I desire you will give me leave to be sometimes so accoustred and act the part of your loving Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: I shall never desire to have any other loving Servant then your Self.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Nor I any other loving Mistress then Your- Self.

lg.l: More innocent Lovers never can there be,
Then my most Princely Lover, that's a She.
Nor never Convent did such pleasures give,
Where Lovers with their Mistresses may live.

div.stage: [Enter a Lady, asking whether they will see the Play.]

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: May it please your Highness, the Play is ready to be Acted.
sp.note: [The Scene is opened, the Princess and LadyHappy sit down, and the Play is Acted within the Scene; the Princess and the LadyHappy being Spectators.]

div.stage: [Enter one drest like a Man that speaks the Prologue.]

lg.l: Noble Spectators, you shall see to night
A Play, which though't be dull, yet's short to sight;
For, since we cannot please your Ears with Wit,
We will not tyre your limbs, long here to fit.

sp.speaker: First Woman
sp.p: O Neighbour well met, where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: I have been with my Neighbour the Cobler’s Wife to comfort her for the loss of her Husband, who is run away with Goody Mettle the Tinker’s Wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: I would to Heaven my Husband would run away with Goody Shredthe Botcher’s Wife, for he lies all day drinking in an Ale-house, like a drunken Rogue as he is, and when he comes home, he beats me all black and blew, when I and my Children are almost starved for want.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: Truly Neighbour, so doth my Husband; and spends not only what he gets, but what I earn with the sweat of my brows, the whilst my Children cry for bread, and he drinks that away, that should feed my small Children, which are too young to work for themselves.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: But I will go, and pull my Husband out of the Ale-house, or I’le break their Lattice-windows down.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: Come, I’le go and help; for my Husband is there too: but we shall be both beaten by them.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: I care not: for I will not suffer him to be drunk, and I and my Children starve; I had better be dead.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Oh, I am sick!

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: You are breeding a Child, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I have not one minutes time of health.

sp.speaker: First Lady
sp.p: Why weep you, Madam?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: Have I not cause to weep when my Husband hath play’d all his Estate away at Dice and Cards, even to the Clothes on his back?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: I have as much cause to weep then as you; for, though my Husband hath not lost his Estate at play, yet he hath spent it amongst his Whores; and is not content to keep Whores abroad, but in my house, under my roof, and they must rule as chief Mistresses.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: But my Husband hath not only lost his own Estate, but also my Portion; and hath forced me with threats, to yield up my Jointure, so that I must beg for my living, for any thing I know as yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: If all Married Women were as unhappy as I, Marriage were a curse.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: No doubt of it.

div.head: Scene V.
div.stage: [Enter a Lady, as almost distracted, running about the Stage, and her Maid follows her.]

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Oh! my Child is dead, my Child is dead, what shall I do, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: You must have patience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Who can have patience to lose their only Child? who can! Oh I shall run mad, for I have no patience.

div.stage: [Runs off the Stage. Exit Maid after her.]

div.head: Scene VI.
div.stage: Enter a Citizen’s Wife, as into a Tavern, where a Bush is hung out, and meets some Gentlemen there.

sp.speaker: Citizen's Wife
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, is my Husband, Mr. Negligent here?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: He was, but he is gone some quarter of an hour since.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: Could he go, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Yes, with a Supporter.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: Out upon him! must he be supported? Upon my credit Gentlemen, he will undo himself and me too, with his drinking and carelesness, leaving his Shop and all his Commodities at six’s and seven’s; and his Prentices and Journey-men are as careless and idle as he; besides, they cozen him of his Wares. But, was it a He or She-Supporter, my Husband was supported by?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: A She-supporter; for it was one of the Maid- servants, which belong to this Tavern.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: Out upon him Knave, must he have a She-supporter, in the Devil’s name? but I’le go and seek them both out with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Pray, let us intreat your stay to drink a cup of Wine with us.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: I will take your kind Offer; for Wine may chance to abate Cholerick vapours, and pacifie the Spleen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: That it will; for Wine and good Company are the only abaters of Vapours.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: It doth not abate Vapours so much as cure Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: In truth, I find a cup of Wine doth comfort me sometimes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: It will cheer the Heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Yes, and enlighten the Understanding.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife
sp.p: Indeed, and my understanding requires enlightening.

div.head: Scene VII.
div.stage: [Enter a Lady big with Child, groaning as in labour, and a Company of Women with her.]

sp.p: Oh my back, my back will break, Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: Is the Midwife sent for?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: Yes, but she is with another Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Oh my back! Oh! Oh! Oh! Juno, give me some ease.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: I have brought my Son into the World with great pains, bred him with tender care, much pains and great cost; and must he now be hang’d for killing a Man in a quarrel? when he should be a comfort and staff of my age, is he to be my ages affliction?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: I confess it is a great affliction; but I have had as great; having had but two Daughters, and them fair ones, though I say it, and might have matched them well: but one of them was got with Child to my great disgrace; th’ other run away with my Butler, not worth the droppings of his Taps.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: Who would desire Children, since they come to such misfortunes?

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: Is the Midwife come, for my Lady is in a strong labour?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: No, she cannot come, for she hath been with a Lady that hath been in strong labour these three days of a dead child, and ’tis thought she cannot be delivered.

sp.speaker: 3 Woman
sp.p: Come away, the Midwife is come.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman
sp.p: Is the Lady deliver’d, she was withall?

sp.speaker: 3 Woman
sp.p: Yes, of life; for she could not be delivered, and so she died.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman
sp.p: Pray tell not our Lady so: for, the very fright of not being able to bring forth a Child will kill her.

div.head: Scene X.
div.stage: [Enter a Gentleman who meets a fair Young Lady.]

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: Madam, my Lord desires you to command whatsoever you please, and it shall be obey’d.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I dare not command, but I humbly intreat, I may live quiet and free from his Amours.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: He says he cannot live, and not love you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But he may live, and not lie with me.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: He cannot be happy, unless he enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And I must be unhappy, if he should.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: He commanded me to tell you that he will part from his Lady for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Heaven forbid, I should part Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: Lady, he will be divorced for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Heaven forbid I should be the cause of a Divorce between a Noble Pair.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: You had best consent; for, otherwise he will have you against your will.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I will send his Lordship an answer to morrow; pray him to give me so much time.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: I shall, Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I must prevent my own ruin, and the sweet virtuous Ladies, by going into a Nunnery; wherefore, I’le put my self into one to night:

lg.l: There will I live, and serve the Gods on high,
And leave this wicked World and Vanity.
Marriage is a Curse we find,
Especially to Women kind:
From the Cobler’s Wife we see,
To Ladies, they unhappie be.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Pray Servant, how do you like this Play?

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: My sweet Mistress, I cannot in conscience approve of it; for though some few be unhappy in Marriage, yet there are many more that are so happy as they would not change their condition.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: O Servant, I fear you will become an Apostate.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Not to you sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: There is no hopes of dissolving this Convent of Pleasure.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.p: Faith, not as I can perceive.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent
sp.p: We may be sure, this Convent will never be dissolved, by reason it is ennobled with the company of great Princesses, and glorified with a great Fame; but the fear is, that all the rich Heirs will make Convents, and all the Young Beauties associate themselves in such Convents.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.p: You speak reason; wherefore, let us endeavour to get Wives, before they are Incloister’d.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: [Enter Lady Happy drest as a Shepherdess; She walks very Melancholy, then speaks as to her self.]

sp.p: My Name is Happy, and so was my Condition, before I saw this Princess; but now I am like to be the most unhappy Maid alive: But why may not I love a Woman with the same affection I could a Man?

lg.l: No, no, Nature is Nature, and still will be
The same she was from all Eternity.

div.stage: [Enter the Princess in Masculine Shepherd’s Clothes.]

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: My dearest Mistress, do you shun my Company? is your Servant become an offence to your sight?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: No, Servant! your Presence is more acceptable to me then the Presence of our Goddess Nature, for which she, I fear will punish me, for loving you more then I ought to love you.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Can Lovers love too much?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Yes, if they love not well.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Can any Love be more vertuous, innocent and harmless then ours?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Then let us please our selves, as harmless Lovers use to do.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: How can harmless Lovers please themselves?

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Why very well, as, to discourse, imbrace and kiss, so mingle souls together.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: But innocent Lovers do not use to kiss.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Not any act more frequent amongst us Women-kind; nay, it were a sin in friendship, should not we kiss: then let us not prove our selves Reprobates.

div.stage: [They imbrace and kiss, and hold each other in their Arms.]

lg.l: These my Imbraces though of Femal kind,
May be as fervent as a Masculine mind.

div.stage: [The Scene is open’d, the Princess and LadyHappy go in. A Pastoral within the Scene.]
[The Scene is changed into a Green, or Plain, where Sheep are feeding, and a May-Pole in the middle.]
[LadyHappy as a Shepherdess, and the Princess as a Shepherd are sitting there.]
[Enter another Shepherd, and Wooes the Lady Happy.]

lg.l: Fair Shepherdess do not my Suit deny,
O grant my Suit, let me not for Love die:
Pity my Flocks, Oh save their Shepherd’s life;
Grant you my Suit, be you their Shepherd’s Wife.
How can I grant to every ones request?
Each Shepherd’s Suit lets me not be at rest;
For which I wish, the Winds might blow them far,
That no Love-Suit might enter to my Ear.

div.stage: [Enter Madam Mediator in a Shepherdess dress, and another Shepherd.]

lg.l: Good Dame unto your Daughter speak for me.
Perswade her I your Son in Law may be:
I’le serve your Swine, your Cows bring home to Milk;
Attend your Sheep, whose Wool’s as soft as Silk;
I’le plow your Grounds, Corn I’le in Winter sow,
Then reap your Harvest, and your Grass I’le mow;
Gather your Fruits in Autumn from the Tree.
All this and more I’le do, if y’ speak for me.
My Daughter vows a single life,
And swears, she n’re will be a Wife;
But live a Maid, and Flocks will keep,
And her chief Company shall be Sheep.

div.stage: [The Princess as a Shepherd, speaks to the Lady Happy.]

lg.l: My Shepherdess, your Wit flies high,
Up to the Skie,
And views the Gates of Heaven,
Which are the Planets Seven;
Sees how fixt Stars are plac’d,
And how the Meteors wast;
What makes the Snow so white,
And how the Sun makes light;
What makes the biting Cold
On every thing take hold;
And Hail a mixt degree,
’Twixt Snow and Ice you see
From whence the Winds do blow;
What Thunder is, you know,
And what makes Lightning flow
Like liquid streams, you show.
From Skie you come to th’ Earth,
And view each Creature’s birth;
Sink to the Center deep,
Where all dead bodies sleep;
And there observe to know,
What makes the Minerals grow;
How Vegetables sprout,
And how the Plants come out;
Take notice of all Seed,
And what the Earth doth breed;
Then view the Springs below,
And mark how Waters flow;
What makes the Tides to rise
Up proudly to the Skies,
And shrinking back descend,
As fearing to offend.
Also your Wit doth view
The Vapour and the Dew,
In Summer’s heat, that Wet
Doth seem like the Earth’s Sweat;
In Winter-time, that Dew
Like paint’s white to the view,
Cold makes that thick, white, dry;
As Cerusse it doth lie
On th’ Earth’s black face, so fair
As painted Ladies are;
But, when a heat is felt,
That Frosty paint doth melt.
Thus Heav’n and Earth you view,
And see what’s Old, what’s New;
How Bodies Transmigrate,
Lives are Predestinate.
Thus doth your Wit reveal
What Nature would conceal.
My Shepherd,
All those that live do know it,
That you are born a Poet,
Your Wit doth search Mankind,
In Body and in Mind;
The Appetites you measure,
And weigh each several Pleasure;
Do figure every Passion,
And every Humor’s fashion;
See how the Fancie’s wrought,
And what makes every Thought;
Fadom Conceptions low,
From whence Opinions flow;
Observe the Memorie’s length,
And Understanding’s strength
Your Wit doth Reason find,
The Centre of the Mind,
Wherein the Rational Soul
Doth govern and controul,
There doth she sit in State,
Predestinate by Fate,
And by the Gods Decree,
That Sovereign She should be.
And thus your Wit can tell,
How Souls in Bodies dwell;
As that the Mind dwells in the Brain,
And in the Mind the Soul doth raign,
And in the Soul the life doth last,
For with the Body it doth not wast;
Nor shall Wit like the Body die,
But live in the World’s Memory.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: May I live in your favour, and be possest with your Love and Person, is the height of my ambitions.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: I can neither deny you my Love nor Person.

lg.l: In amorous Pastoral Verse we did not Woo.
As other Pastoral Lovers use to doo.
Which doth express, we shall more constant be,
And in a Married life better agree.
We shall agree, for we true Love inherit,
Join as one Body and Soul, or Heav’nly Spirit.

div.stage: [Here come Rural Sports, as Country Dances about the May-Pole: that Pair which Dances best is Crowned King and Queen of the Shepherds that year; which happens to the Princess, and the Lady Happy.]

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Let me tell you, Servant, that our Custome is to dance about this May-Pole, and that Pair which Dances best is Crown’d King and Queen of all the Shepherds and Shepherdesses this year: Which Sport if it please you we will begin.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Nothing, Sweetest Mistress, that pleases you, can displease me.
sp.stage: [They Dance; after the Dancing the Princess and Lady Happy are Crowned with a Garland of Flowers: a Shepherd speaks.]

lg.l: You’ve won the prize; and justly; so we all
Acknowledg it with joy, and offer here
Our Hatchments up, our Sheep-hooks as your due,
And Scrips of Corduant, and Oaten pipe;
So all our Pastoral Ornaments we lay
Here at your Feet, with Homage to obay
All your Commands, and all these things we bring
In honour of our dancing Queen and King;
For Dancing heretofore has got more Riches
Then we can find in all our Shepherds Breeches;
Witness rich Holmby: Long then may you live,
And for your Dancing what we have we give.

div.stage: [A Wassel is carried about and Syllibubs.]
[Another Shepherd speaks, or Sings this that follows.]

lg.l: The Jolly Wassel now do bring,
With Apples drown’d in stronger Ale,
And fresher Syllibubs, and sing;
Then each to tell their Love-sick Tale:
So home by Couples, and thus draw
Our selves by holy Hymen’s Law.

div.stage: [Enter the Princess Sola, and walks a turn or two in a Musing posture, then views her Self, and speaks.]

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: What have I on a Petticoat, Oh Mars! thou God of War, pardon my sloth; but yet remember thou art a Lover, and so am I; but you will say, my Kingdom wants me, not only to rule, and govern it, but to defend it: But what is a Kingdom in comparison of a Beautiful Mistress? Base thoughts flie off, for I will not go; did not only a Kingdom, but the World want me.

div.stage: [Enter the Lady Happy Sola, and Melancholy, and after a short Musing speaks.]

lg.l: O Nature, O you gods above,
Suffer me not to fall in Love;
O strike me dead here in this place
Rather then fall into disgrace.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: What, Lady Happy, ſolitary alone! and Muſing like a diſconſolate Lover!

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: No, I was Meditating of Holy things.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Holy things! what Holy things?

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Why, ſuch Holy things as the Gods are.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: By my truth, whether your Contemplation be of Gods or of Men, you are become lean and pale ſince I was in the Convent laſt.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Come my ſweet Miſtreſs, ſhall we go to our Sports and Recreations?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Beſhrew me, your Highneſs hath ſported too much I fear.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Why, Madam Mediator, ſay you ſo?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Becauſe the Lady Happy looks not well, ſhe is become pale and lean.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Madam Mediator, your eyes are become dim with Time; for my ſweet Miſtreſs appears with greater ſplendor then the God of Light.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: For all you are a great Princeſs, give me leave to tell you,

lg.l: I am not ſo old, nor yet ſo blind,
But that I ſee you are too kind.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Well, Madam Mediator, when we return from our Recreations, I will ask your pardon, for ſaying, your eyes are dim, conditionally you will ask pardon for ſaying, my Miſtreſs looks not well.

div.stage: The Scene is opened, and there is preſented a Rock as in the Sea, whereupon ſits the Princeſs and the Lady Happy; the Princeſs as the Sea-God Neptune, the Lady Happy as a Sea-Goddeſs: the reſt of the Ladies ſit ſomewhat lower, dreſt like Water-Nymphs; the Princeſs begins to ſpeak a Speech in Verſe, and after her the Lady Happy makes her Speech.

lg.l: I Am the King of all the Seas,
All Watry Creatures do me pleaſe,
Obey my Power and Command,
And bring me Preſents from the Land;
The Waters open their Flood-gates,
Where Ships do paſs, ſent by the Fates;
Which Fates do yearly, as May-Dew,
Send me a Tribute from Peru,
From other Nations beſides,
Brought by their Servants, Winds and Tides,
Ships fraught and Men to me they bring;
My Watery Kingdom lays them in.
Thus from the Earth a Tribute I
Receive, which ſhews my power thereby:
Beſides, my Kingdom’s richer far
Then all the Earth and every Star.
I feed the Sun, which gives them light,
And makes them ſhine in darkeſt night,
Moiſt vapour from my breſt I give,
Which he ſucks forth, and makes him live,
Or elſe his Fire would ſoon go out,
Grow dark, or burn the World throughout.
What Earthly Creature’s like to me,
That hath ſuch Power and Majeſtie?
My Palaces are Rocks of Stone,
And built by Nature’s hand alone;
No baſe, diſſembling, coz’ning Art
Do I imploy in any part,
In all my Kingdom large and wide,
Nature directs and doth provide
Me all Proviſions which I need,
And Cooks my Meat on which I feed.
My Cabinets are Oyſter-ſhells,
In which I keep my Orient-Pearls,
To open them I uſe the Tide,
As Keys to Locks, which opens wide,
The Oyſter-ſhells then out I take;
Thoſe, Orient-Pearls and Crowns do make;
And modeſt Coral I do wear,
Which bluſhes when it touches air.
On Silver-Waves I ſit and ſing,
And then the Fiſh lie liſtening:
Then ſitting on a Rocky ſtone,
I comb my Hair with Fiſhes bone;
The whil’ſt Apollo, with his Beams,
Doth dry my Hair from wat’ry ſtreams.
His Light doth glaze the Water’s face,
Make the large Sea my Looking-Glaſs;
So when I ſwim on Waters high,
I ſee my ſelf as I glide by:
But when the Sun begins to burn,
I back into my Waters turn,
And dive unto the bottom low:
Then on my head the Waters flow,
In Curled waves and Circles round;
And thus with Waters am I Crown’d.
Beſides, within the Waters deep,
In hollow Rocks my Court I keep;
Of Amber-greece my Bed is made,
Whereon my ſofter Limbs are laid,
There take I Reſt; and whil’ſt I ſleep,
The Sea doth guard, and ſafe me keep
From danger; and, when I awake,
A Preſent of a Ship doth make.
No Prince on Earth hath more reſort,
Nor keeps more Servants in his Court;
Of Mare-maids you’re waited on,
And Mare-men do attend upon
My Perſon; ſome are Councellors,
Which order all my great Affairs;
Within my wat’ry Kingdom wide,
They help to rule, and ſo to guide
The Common-wealth; and are by me
Prefer’d unto an high degree.
Some Judges are, and Magiſtrates,
Decide each Cauſe, and end Debates;
Others, Commanders in the War;
And ſome to Governments prefer;
Others are Neptun’s Prieſts which pray
And preach when is a Holy-day.
And thus with Method order I,
And govern all with Majeſty;
I am ſole Monarch of the Sea,
And all therein belongs to me.
We Watery Nymphs Rejoyce and Sing
About God Neptune our Sea’s King;
In Sea-green Habits, for to move
His God-head, for to fall in love.
That with his Trident he doth ſtay
Rough foaming Billows which obay:
And when in Triumph he doth ſtride
His manag’d Dolphin for to ride.
All his Sea-people to his wiſh,
From Whale to Herring ſubject Fiſh,
With Acclamations do attend him,
And pray’s more Riches ſtill to ſend him.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: [Enter the Princeſs and the Lady Happy; The Princeſs is in a Man’s Apparel as going to Dance; they Whiſper ſometime; ſometime; then the Lady Happy takes a Ribbon from her arm, and gives it to the Princeſs, who gives her another inſtead of that, and kiſſes her hand. They go in and come preſently out again with all the Company to Dance, the Muſick plays; And after they have Danced a little while, in comes Madam Mediator wringing her hands, and ſpreading her arms; and full of Paſſion cries out.]

sp.p: O Ladies, Ladies! you’re all betrayed, undone, undone; for there is a man diſguiſed in the Convent, ſearch and you’l find it.

div.stage: [They all skip from each other, as afraid of each other; only the Princeſs and the Lady Happy stand still together.]

sp.p: You may make the ſearch, Madam Mediator ; but you will quit me, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: By my faith but I will not, for you are moſt to be ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: ut you ſay, the Man is diſguiſed like a Woman, and I am accouſtred like a Man.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Fidle, fadle, that is nothing to the purpoſe.

div.stage: [Enter an Embaſſador to the Prince; the Embaſſador kneels, the Prince bids him riſe.]

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: What came you here for?

sp.speaker: Embass
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Highneſs, The Lords of your Council ſent me to inform your Highneſs, that your Subjects are ſo diſcontented at your Abſence, that if your Highneſs do not return into your Kingdom ſoon, they’l enter this Kingdom by reaſon they hear you are here; and ſome report as if your Highneſs were reſtrained as Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: So I am, but not by the State, but by this Fair Lady, who muſt be your Soveraigneſs.

div.stage: [The Embaſſador kneels and kiſſes her Hand.]

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: But ſince I am diſcover’d, go from me to the Councellors of this State, and inform them of my being here, as alſo the reaſon, and that I ask their leave I may marry this Lady; otherwiſe, tell them I will have her by force of Arms.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: O the Lord! I hope you will not bring an Army, to take away all the Women; will you?

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: No, Madam Mediator, we will leave you behind us.

div.head: Scene II.
div.stage: [Enter Madam Mediator lamenting and crying with a Handkerchief in her hand.]

sp.p: O Gentlemen, that I never had been born, we’re all undone and loſt!

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Matter? nay, I doubt, there’s too much Matter.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: How, never ſuch a Miſtake; why we have taken a Man for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: Why, a Man is for a Woman.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Fidle fadle, I know that as well as you can tell me; but there was a young Man dreſt in Woman’s Apparel, and enter’d our Convent, and the Gods know what he hath done: He is mighty handſome, and that’s a great Temptation to Virtue; but I hope all is well: But this wicked World will lay aſperſion upon any thing or nothing; and therefore I doubt, all my ſweet young Birds are undone, the Gods comfort them. them.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: But could you never diſcover it? nor have no hint he was a Man?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: No truly, only once I ſaw him kiſs the Lady Happy; and you know Womens Kiſſes are unnatural, and me-thought they kiſſed with more alacrity then Women uſe, a kind of Titillation, and more Vigorous.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: Why, did you not then examine it?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Why, they would have ſaid, I was but an old jealous fool, and laught at me; but Experience is a great matter; If the Gods had not been merciful to me, he might have faln upon me.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Why, what if he had?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Nay, if he had I care not: for I defie the Fleſh as much as I renounce the Devil, and the pomp of this wicked World; but if I could but have ſav’d my young ſweet Virgins, I would willingly have ſacrificed my body for them; for we are not born for our ſelves but for others.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: 'Tis piouſly ſaid, truly, lovingly and kindly.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Nay, I have read the Practice of Piety; but further they ſay, He is a Foreign Prince; and they ſay, They’re very hot.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Why, you are Madam Mediator, you muſt mediate and make a Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Ods body what do you talk of Mediation, I doubt they are too good Friends; Well, this will be news for Court, Town and Country, in private Letters, in the Gazette, and in abominable Ballets, before before it be long, and jeered to death by the pretending Wits; Wits; but, good Gentlemen, keep this as a Secret, and let not me be the Author, for you will hear abundantly of it before it be long.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: But, Madam Mediator, this is no Secret, it is known all the Town over, and the State is preparing to entertain the Prince.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Lord! to ſee how ill news will fly ſo ſoon abroad?

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: Ill news indeed for us Wooers.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: We only wooed in Imagination but not in Reality.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: But you all had hopes.

sp.speaker: Advis
sp.p: We had ſo; but ſhe only has the fruition: for it is ſaid, the Prince and ſhe are agreed to Marry; and the State is ſo willing, as they account it an honour, and hope ſhall reap much advantage by the Match.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat
sp.p: Yes, yes; but there is an old and true Saying, There’s much between the Cup and the Lip.

div.head: Scene III.
div.stage: [Enter the Prince as Bridegroom, and the Lady Happy as Bride, hand in hand under a Canopy born over their heads by Men; the Magiſtrates march before, then the Hoboys; and then the Bridal-Gueſts, as coming from the Church, where they were Married.]
[All the Company bids them joy, they thank them.]

sp.speaker: Madam Mediator
sp.p: Although your Highneſs will not ſtay to feaſt with your Gueſts, pray Dance before you go.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: We will both Dance and Feaſt before we go; come Madam let us Dance, to pleaſe Madam Mediator.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Now, Noble Friends, Dance you; and the Princeſs, and I, will reſt our ſelves.

div.stage: [After they have Danced, the Lady Happy, as now Princeſs , ſpeaks to the Lady Vertue.]

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Lady Vertue, I perceive you keep Mimick ſtill.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Sir, this is the Mimick I told you of.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: Mimick, will you leave your Lady and go with me?

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: I am a Married Man, and have Married my Ladies Maid Nan, and ſhe will keep me at home do what I can; but you’ve now a Mimick of your own, for the Prince has imitated a Woman.

sp.speaker: L. Happy
sp.p: What you Rogue, do you call me a Fool?

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: Not I, pleaſe your Highneſs, unleſs all Women be Fools.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Is your Wife a Fool?

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: Man and Wife, 'tis ſaid, makes but one Fool.

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: I have an humble Petition to your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Riſe; What Petition is that?

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: That your Highneſs would be pleaſed to divide the Convent in two equal parts; one for Fools, and th’ other for Married Men, as mad Men.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: I’le divide it for Virgins and Widows.

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: That will prove a Convent of Pleaſure indeed; but but they will never agree, eſpecially if there be ſome diſguiſed Prince amongſt them; but you had better beſtow it on old decrepit and bed-rid Matrons, and then it may be call’d the Convent of Charity, if it cannot poſſibly be named the Convent of Chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Princ
sp.p: Well, to ſhew my Charity, and to keep your Wife’s Chaſtity, I’le beſtow my bounty in a Preſent, on the Condition you ſpeak the Epilogue. Come, Noble Friends, let us feaſt before we part.

sp.speaker: Mimick
sp.p: An Epilogue ſays he, the devil an Epilogue have I: let me ſtudy.

I have it, I have it; No faith, I have it not; I lie, I have it, I ſay, I have it not; Fie Mimick, will you lie? Yes, Mimick, I will lie, if it be my pleaſure: But I ſay, it is gone; What is gone? The Epilogue; When had you it? I never had it; then you did not loſe it; that is all one, but I muſt ſpeak it, although I never had it; How can you ſpeak it, and never had it? I marry, that’s the queſtion; but words are nothing, and then an Epilogue is nothing, and ſo I may ſpeak nothing; Then nothing be my Speech.

lg.l: Noble Spectators by this Candle-light,
I know not what to ſay, but bid, Good Night:
I dare not beg Applauſe, our Poeteſs then
Will be enrag’d, and kill me with her Pen;
For ſhe is careleſs, and is void of fear;
If you diſlike her Play ſhe doth not care.
But I ſhall weep, my inward Grief ſhall ſhow
Through Floods of Tears, that through my Eyes will flow.
And ſo poor Mimick he for ſorrow die.
And then through pity you may chance to cry:
But if you pleaſe, you may a Cordial give,
Made up with Praiſe, and ſo he long may live.

castItem.role: Monsieur Take-pleasure, and Dick his Man.
A distracted Lady, and her Maid.
A Gentleman and a Young Lady.
